channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Xi’s Strategy to Win Taiwan Without Fighting
item.description: The West anticipates an invasion. Beijing trusts its 15th Five-Year Plan.

item.title: China’s Taiwan Drills Are Crossing a New Line
item.description: Military exercises seek to erase vital buffer zone between China and Taiwan.

item.title: Beijing’s Invisible Network: United Front Operations in the Philippines
item.description: Philippine officials acknowledge how united front work is used by the CCP to influence various sectors, overtly and covertly. What remains lacking is a full appreciation of its scope.

item.title: Ukraine as a Model, a Warning, and a Partner for Taiwan’s Drone Industry
item.description: Every minute of the Russo-Ukrainian war has showcased the level of adaptation needed for survival, presenting Taiwan with both a model and a warning: act fast or suffer losses.

item.title: Trump’s Travel Bans Threaten US National Security
item.description: For all Donald Trump’s talk about security, he proves far more interested in lining his own pockets. No country that hosts a major Trump-branded property or strikes a high-profile business deal with a member of Trump’s inner circle – including some with well-documented ties to global terrorism – faces US travel restrictions.

item.title: Nepal’s ‘Alternative’ Alliance: Generational Shift or Politics as Usual?
item.description: Electoral coalitions are not new in Nepali politics. What distinguishes this one is the promise that it will deliver a different kind of politics.

item.title: How will the mass protests that are convulsing Iran unfold?
item.description: Binyamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump may shape how the regime reacts to new unrest

item.title: The Case for Universalism in a Fragmenting World
item.description: The current wave of hyper-nationalism reflects growing anxiety over a deeply interconnected global economy that no longer fits neatly within political borders. While a world without nation-states remains a distant dream, we can at least strengthen existing supranational organizations.

item.title: Energy Will Decide the AI Race
item.description: Although the race to dominate AI has so far focused on cutting-edge chips and capital expenditures, all the data centers in the world will not help you if they lack a continuous supply of affordable energy. While China clearly understands this, America may not, and that could create an opportunity for Europe.

item.title: Ukraine: Reacting to ‘Russian Fakes’ Beneath the Dignity of Central Asian States
item.description: In the aftermath of an alleged attack on one of Putin's residences, the Central Asian governments came out quickly with calls and condemnations, surprising Ukraine.

item.title: South Korea’s Digital Divide Is Becoming a Generational Governance Challenge
item.description: In South Korea, digital fluency is quietly becoming a condition for participation in all areas of society, deepening generational divides in a rapidly aging country.

item.title: The Truth About Europe’s Regulation of Digital Platforms
item.description: US President Donald Trump claims that Europeans are engaging in "censorship" when they require digital platforms to be transparent about their algorithms and to remove already illegal content. With the US recently barring entry to five Europeans it accuses of regulating online content, it is time to set the record straight.

item.title: How ‘Green’ Narratives Are Used to Dismantle Indigenous Rights in India
item.description: Laws like the Forest Rights Act have been systematically eroded by the very state institutions responsible for implementing them.

item.title: China-India Relations in 2026: Can the Thaw Continue?
item.description: After a year of progress, China-India relations are advancing into a more difficult but more productive period.

item.title: How China Turned Phone Games Into Stadium Spectacle
item.description: Chinese firms and regulators helped make the smartphone the country’s default entertainment device. Now mobile games are a flagship cultural industry.

item.title: Transition Without Change: Kazakhstan’s Tokayev Era
item.description: Kazakhstan has undergone a transition of power without fundamental change in the regime.

item.title: What’s Ahead for Latin America in 2026?
item.description: The top stories we’re watching this year.

item.title: The Post-2025 World Order
item.description: Last year will be remembered as one of global reckoning. The future of the international order remains unknown, but now we know which countries are best prepared to adapt to the loss of what came before.

item.title: Welcome to the Age of Chaos
item.description: The top global risks of 2026 show an ever more unstable world.

item.title: 2025 in review: Ideas
Israel Unbound
item.description: While the United States and its allies finally led a push to end the Gaza war in 2025, it is not clear how regional stability will be restored, or what shape a new regional order will assume. For the foreseeable future, the Middle East will be bracing for a prolonged conflict as Israel pursues military supremacy.

item.title: Can high-intensity interval training get you fit in a hurry?
item.description: Yes, but be prepared to suffer

item.title: Return of the ‘Dark Side’
item.description: Under the Trump Administration, torture is back in play

item.title: Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami Draws NCP and LDP Into an Islamist Alliance
item.description: It will help the party shed its baggage of having opposed Bangladesh’s liberation in 1971, and attract the support of young participants in the July uprising.

item.title: The Syndrome of Trembling Pens
item.description: How prison is constructed in the writer’s mind before the gavel falls

item.title: Mainland Southeast Asia: What to Watch in 2026
item.description: The past year has been eventful and at times tumultuous for the subregion. Expect more of the same over the coming year.

item.title: The New Arteries of Power
item.description: Subsea Cables Are This Century’s Hidden Battleground

item.title: How Multilateralism Can Survive
item.description: Global institutions are declining, but regional cooperation can fill the gap.

item.title: Indonesian Criminal Code Comes Into Effect Amid Civil Society Criticisms
item.description: The new code, passed in 2022, has replaced the colonial-era penal code introduced by the Dutch before 1945.
